children.name: DataTags provides a unified walk through U.S. privacy jurisprudence to recommend practices for sharing data.
. A user walks through a decision-tree, answering questions about the data that is to be shared.
. The end result is a vector of tags that describe recommended security and handling requirements when sharing the data.
. The focus is on sharing research data widely, but much of the information and process should be generally useful for non-research data.
. Attestations made by the researcher are accepted without review unless stated otherwise.
Tags: [Code, Handling tags, DataType tags, DUA tags, IP tags].
. Code: one of {BLUE, GREEN, YELLOW, ORANGE, RED, CRIMSON}
. BLUE: is non-confidential information that can be stored and shared freely.
. GREEN: is potentially identifiable but not harmful personal information, shared with some access control.
. YELLOW: is potentially harmful personal information, shared with loosely verified and/or approved recipients.
. ORANGE: may include sensitive, identifiable personal information, shared with verified and/or approved recipients under agreement.
. RED: is very sensitive identifiable personal information, shared with strong verification of approved recipients under signed agreement.
. CRIMSON: requires explicit permission for each transaction, using strong verification of approved recipients under signed agreement
. Handling tags [storage, transit, authentication]. Specify how data are stored and delivered.
.Handling: storage: one of {clear, encrypt, double encrypt}.
.Handling: transit: one of {clear, encrypt, double encrypt}.
.Handling: authentication: set of {none, email, OAuth, password}.
. None: available to anonymous individuals.
. Email: available to individuals with verified email addresses.
. OAuth: available to individuals with verified online identity or mobile phone.
. Password: available to individuals having password accounts on system.
. DataType tags [standards, effort, harm]. Describe data and risks related to the dataset.
.DataType: standards: set of {not applicable, HIPAA, FERPA, Electronic wiretapping, Common Rule, etc.}.
. Not Applicable: data does not contain personal (or person-specific) information.
. Consent: explicit informed consent or the permission of each person whose information appears in the data.
. HIPAA: governs personal health information from hospitals, healthcare providers, insurance companies, and their business associates.
. HIPAA Safe Harbor: an approved redaction of fields (e.g., dates in years and first 2 digits of ZIPs).
. HIPAA Statistician: expert asserts that there is minimal risk of re-identification.
. HIPAA Limited Data Set: data acquired under a HIPAA Limited Data Use Agreement.
. HIPAA Business Associate: data acquired under a HIPAA Business Associate Agreement.
. HIPAA Covered Entity: data directly from a HIPAA Covered entity.
.DataType: effort: one of {not applicable}, {identified, identifiable, de-identified, anonymous} or {easy, moderate, difficult, impractical, impossible}.
.DataType: harm: one of {no risk, minimal, shame, civil, criminal, max control}
. no risk: not person-specific information or provably anonymous information.
. minimal: sufficiently de-identified information in which no person can be re-identified.
. shame: identifiable information that could damage a person's reputation or cause embarrassment if exposed.
. shame example: school or academic information
. civil: identifiable information that could reasonably present a non-minimal risk of civil liability if exposed.
. civil examples: Social Security numbers or moderate psychological harm
. criminal: identifiable information that could cause significant harm to an individual if exposed.
. criminal examples: serious criminal liability, serious psychological harm, loss of insurability or employability
. max control: segmented and sequestered even from system administrators
. DUA tags [timelimit, sharing, reidentify, publication, use, acceptance, approval]. Terms and handling of the data use agreement.
.DUA: timelimit: one of {none, 1yr, 2yr, 5yr}
.DUA: sharing: one of {anyone, not online, organization, group, no one}
.DUA: reidentify: one of {no matching, no entities, no people, no prohibition, reidentify, contact}
.DUA: publication: one of {no restriction, notify, pre-approve, prohibited}
.DUA: use: one of {no restriction, research, IRB, no product}
.DUA: acceptance: one of {click, signed, sign with ID}
. Click: terms agreed to by clicking acknowledgement
. Sign: terms agreed to by submitting digitally signed document
. Sign with ID: terms agreed to by submitting signed document and accompanying government issued ID
.DUA: approval: one of {none, email, signed}
. None: no approval by data provider required
. Email: email approval by provider of submitted agreement
. Signed: digitally signed approval from data provider
. IP tags [...inherited from Creative Commons...].  To be done, but not done in this version.
1. Person-specific. Does your data include personal information?
No. 1.1. Tags= [GREEN, store=clear, transfer=clear, auth=none, basis=not applicable, identity=not person-specific, harm=negligible]. END.
children.tags: [GREEN, store=clear, transfer=clear, auth=none, basis=not applicable, identity=not person-specific, harm=none]

children.name: 2. Explicit consent. Did each person whose information appears in the data give explicit permission to share the data?
Yes. 2.1. Did the consent have any restrictions on sharing?
No. 2.1.1. Tags= [GREEN, store=clear, transfer=clear, auth=none, basis=Consent, effort=___, harm=___]. END.
children.tags: [GREEN, store=clear, transfer=clear, auth=none, basis=Consent, effort=___, harm=___]

children.name: Yes. 2.1.2. Add DUA terms using DUA subroutine. Tags= [___, ___,___, ___,, basis=Consent, ___,___]. END.
3. Medical Records. Does the data contain personal health information?
Yes. 3.1. HIPAA. Was the data received from a HIPAA covered entity or a business associate of one?
Yes. 3.1.1. Safe Harbor. Does the data visually adhere to the HIPAA Safe Harbor Provision (e.g., dates in years and first 2 digits of ZIPs)?
Yes. 3.1.1.1. Do you know of a way to put names to the patients in the data?
No. 3.1.1.1.1. Tags= [GREEN, store=clear, transfer=clear, auth=none, basis=HIPAA Safe Harbor, effort=de-identified, harm=negligible]. END.
children.tags: [GREEN, store=clear, transfer=clear, auth=none, basis=HIPAA Safe Harbor, effort=de-identified, harm=negligible]

children.name: Yes. 3.1.2. Statistician Provision. Has an expert certified the data as being of minimal risk?
Yes. 3.1.2.1. Tags= [GREEN, store=clear, transfer=clear, auth=none, basis=HIPAA Statistician, effort=de-identified, harm=negligible]. END.
children.tags: [GREEN, store=clear, transfer=clear, auth=none, basis=HIPAA Statistician, effort=de-identified, harm=negligible]

children.name: Yes. 3.1.3. Limited Data Set. Did you acquire the data under a HIPAA limited data use agreement?
Yes. 3.1.3.1. Did the limited data use agreement have any additional restrictions on sharing?
children.tags: [ORANGE, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA Limited Dataset, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]

children.name: No. 3.1.3.1.1. Tags= [ORANGE, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA Limited Dataset, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]. END.
children.tags: [ORANGE, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA Limited Dataset, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]

children.name: Yes. 3.1.3.1.2. Add DUA terms using DUA subroutine. Tags= [ORANGE, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA Limited Dataset, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]. END.
children.tags: [ORANGE, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA Limited Dataset, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]

children.name: Yes. 3.1.4. Business Associate. Did you acquire the data under a HIPAA Business Associate agreement?
Yes. 3.1.4.1. Did the business associate agreement have any additional restrictions on sharing?
children.tags: [RED, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA Business Associate, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]

children.name: No. 3.1.4.1.1. Tags= [RED, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA Business Associate, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]. END.
children.tags: [RED, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA BAA, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]

children.name: Yes. 3.1.4.1.1. Add DUA terms using DUA subroutine. Tags= [RED, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA Business Associate, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]. END.
children.tags: [RED, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA BAA, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]

children.name: Yes. 3.1.5. Covered. Are you an entity that is directly or indirectly covered by HIPAA?
Yes. 3.1.5.1. Tags= [RED, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA Business Associate, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]. END.
children.tags: [RED, store=encrypt, transfer=encrypt, auth=Approval, basis=HIPAA BAA, effort=identifiable, harm=criminal]

children.name: No. 3.2. Not HIPAA. Examples include statewide discharge data, some prescription data, online and apps data.
3.2.1. Did the data have any restrictions on sharing (e.g., stated in an agreement or policy statement)?
No. 3.2.1.1. Tags= [GREEN, store=clear, transfer=clear, auth=none, basis=Agreement, effort=___, harm=___]. END.
children.tags: [GREEN, store=clear, transfer=clear, auth=none, basis=Consent, effort=___, harm=___]

children.name: Yes. 3.2.1.2. Add DUA terms using DUA subroutine. Tags= [___, ___,___, ___,, basis=Agreement, ___,___]. END.
END. This version processes Consent and Medical data only.
4. Arrest and Conviction Records.
5. Bank and Financial Records.
6. Cable Television.
7. Computer Crime.
8. Credit reporting and Investigations (including ‘Credit Repair,’ ‘Credit Clinics,’ Check-Cashing and Credit Cards).
9. Criminal Justice Information Systems.
10. Electronic Surveillance (including Wiretapping, Telephone Monitoring, and Video Cameras).
11. Employment Records.
12. Government Information on Individuals.
13. Identity Theft.
14. Insurance Records (including use of Genetic Information).
15. Library Records.
16. Mailing Lists (including Video rentals and Spam).
17. Special Medical Records (including HIV Testing).
18. Non-Electronic Visual Surveillance (also Breast-Feeding).
19. Polygraphing in Employment.
20. Privacy Statutes/State Constitutions (including the Right to Publicity).
21. Privileged Communications.
22. Social Security Numbers.
23. Student Records.
24. Tax Records.
25. Telephone Services (including Telephone Solicitation and Caller ID)
26. Testing in Employment (including Urinalysis, Genetic and Blood Tests).
27. Tracking Technologies.
28. Voter Records.
